In this session we will be discussing from the 25th verse of the 19th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
Tatra Bhavad Bhagavan Vyasa Putro Yadritcha Yagam Atamano Anapekshaha Alakshalingo Nijalabhatushto Vritascha Balair Avadhuta Vesaha
The meaning of this verse is, at that moment there appeared the powerful son of Vyasadeva who travelled over the earth disinterested and satisfied with himself.
He did not manifest any symptoms of belonging to any social order or status of life.
He was surrounded with women and children and he dressed as if others had.
He had neglected him.
This verse describes the appearance of Shukadeva Goswami and that is the title of this chapter.
The appearance of Shukadeva Goswami.
Where is he appearing?
He is appearing in the place where Parikshit Maharaj has decided to sit and fast until death.
In that holy place.
On the bank of the river Ganga.
Where many saintly persons have come from all over the universe to witness Parikshit quitting his body.
And they could also foresee, some of them could foresee that actually Bhagavatam is going to be spoken by Shukadeva Goswami.
So now Shukadeva Goswami has arrived there.
And the description is a wonderful description of Shukadeva Goswami.
He is described, Prabhupada explains that in the purport elaborately.
He is described by so many nice adjectives.
Bhagawan.
Here Bhagawan, Prabhupada says in the purport, in the purport Prabhupada says the word Bhagawan is sometimes used in relation to some of the great devotees of the Lord.
Like Shukadeva Goswami.
Like Shukadeva Goswami.
Bhagawan actually means the supreme personality of Godhead, Krishna.
Bhagawan, one who possesses six particular opulences to an unlimited degree.
That is a precise definition.
Ayishwar Yashya Samagrasya Veer Yashya Yashyasa Shreyaha Gyanavairagya Yoshchaiva Shannambhaga Itingana.
This is very specific.
Specific definition for the word Bhagawan.
When it applies to the supreme personality of Godhead, Krishna.
But here Bhagawan is used for Shukadeva Goswami.
Sometimes Bhagawan is used for Vyasadeva.
Sometimes Bhagawan is used for Narada.
Now when it is used in relation to some of the great devotees of the Lord.
Then it is explained by Prabhupada.
Why?
It doesn't mean that they are God.
No.
Such liberated souls are disinterested in the affairs of this material world.
This is a characteristic.
They are all liberated souls.
So because they are liberated, they are completely pure.
They don't have any taint.
They don't have any taint of material contamination.
They are never touched by any of the three gunas.
Three material modes.
So they are always spiritually active.
They are only engaged in spiritual activities.
Even in this material world.
Now Shri La Prabhupada explains.
Why is it that they are disinterested in the affairs of this material world?
Because they are self-satisfied by great achievements of devotional service.
Devotional service is so satisfying that a person taking satisfaction from always being engaged in devotional service loses all interest in material affairs.
Therefore it is described.
Disinterested in material affairs.
Anapek shah disinterested in material affairs.

Nor did he undergo any formal reformatory performances.
This was explained.

But Shukadeva Goswami did not have to undergo any of these samskaras including Upanayana because he was already a liberated soul. He was realized. He didn't have to study the Vedas.
Shukade Goswami's father Vyasa Deva was his natural spiritual master. Why natural spiritual master? Because Shukade Goswami heard Srimad Bhagavatam from Vyasa Deva, his own father.
Vyasa Deva was compiling the Bhagavatam after being instructed to do so by Narada. This has already been described in an earlier chapter in this first canto, fifth chapter.

Vyasa Deva, after compiling all the Vedic literature, after compiling the Mahabharata, after compiling the other Puranas, Dharmasastras, everything he did, extensive work for the welfare of the human beings, in this Kali Yuga especially, he was dissatisfied, feelings incomplete.
So his spiritual master Narada noticed this dissatisfaction and pointed out,
This dissatisfaction is because none of the literatures you have compiled, in none of them you have exclusively glorified the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna.
So Narada instructed Vyasa Deva to compile this Srimad Bhagavatam, which is the only literature,
which is containing the exclusivity,
exclusive glorification of Krishna and nothing else.
So Vyasa Deva compiled the Bhagavatam exactly according to the instructions of Narada, and when he was revising the Bhagavatam, Shukadeva Goswami heard the Bhagavatam from Vyasa Deva.
Shukadeva Goswami got attracted to the description of Krishna in the Bhagavatam,
so he began inquisitive, who is this personality Krishna? Special personality.
